Award.AwardTitle: Investigating tomographic resolution in global crustal imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
Seismic structure of the Earth's crust is important for the understanding of the formation and evolution of continents and ocean basins. The resolution of current global crustal models are limited by highly inhomogeneous data coverage as refraction and reflection experiments and receiver function analysis are sparse in oceanic regions and remote continent interiors. Seismic surface waves can be potentially used to better constrain crustal structure at a global scale as they propagate in the outer shell of the earth and provide best spatial coverage compared with other seismic data sets. However, understanding the lateral and vertical resolution of surface waves in global crustal tomography remains a challenge. This research will integrate development of finite-frequency theory for Moho discontinuity imaging and wave propagation simulations using the Spectral Element Method to investigate resolution limits of ray theory and finite-frequency theory in surface-wave tomography of global crustal structure.


The PI will develop finite-frequency theory based on travelling-wave mode coupling for imaging the Moho discontinuity topography in anisotropic media and investigate resolution limits in non-linear global crustal tomography based on phase-velocity sensitivity kernels. The team will quantify the scale-dependence of diffractional effects in global crustal models as well as resolution limits associated with approximations in tomographic theory and imperfect global data coverage. The tradeoff between wavespeed and Moho topography will be analyzed in joint inversions of discontinuity topography and wavespeed structure.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth’s interior is divided into several major layers by seismic discontinuities. The discontinuities include the crust-mantle boundary, which separates the crust from the mantle, as well as two additional discontinuities in the mid mantle. Imaging of the crust-mantle boundary is important for us to understand how the continents and ocean floors were formed and how their structures evolve with time. The mid-mantle discontinuities are important for the understanding of mantle convection – a process through which the Earth’s interior cools with time. This work aims to improve the imaging theory for studying the internal discontinuities using seismic waves.

 

Seismic waves produced by natural earthquakes travel through the deep interior of the Earth before returning to the surface of the Earth. By studying seismic waves (ground motions) recorded at seismometers deployed at the surface of the Earth, seismologists can image physical properties of the Earth's interior. In the past decades, the theory has been based on an approximation, therefore, seismologists were only able to obtain a blurred image of the Earth's interior. We improved seismic theory to uses more of the signal from an earthquake than previously used by seismologists. Advanced mathematical and computational theory was necessary in order to use this additional information. It also required advanced supercomputers with much more computational ability than what was available even a few years ago. We applied our new theory to seismic data recorded at the Global Seismological Network and USArray stations. The application of the improved theory in global datasets led us to find out that the crust beneath the oceans is thinner than previously thought and it contains complex structures that were imaged for the first time. The characteristics of the mid-mantle discontinuities are also distinctly different beneath the oceans and subduction zones. In addition, we applied the new imaging theory to seismic data recorded in the Western United States and the most striking feature in the obtained results were “hotspots” beneath the Yellowstone volcanoes, which led us to conclude that volcanisms were caused by an upside-down subduction of a stagnant oceanic Farallon plate in the mantle transition zone, a process started about 16 million years ago.

 

The results have been published in research papers and conference presentations. The new findings have been incorporated in teaching materials in undergraduate and graduate courses taught at Virginia Tech. This grant provided training opportunities for one graduate student.
